items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.
	 
Student Employment Position Establishment  
The establishment of the following position at San Jose City College effective 02/12/14: 
Tobacco Peer Educator, Health Services

items.item_details:
On July 9, 2013 (Board Item F. 14), the Board of Trustees approved a contract amendment to A. Plescia & Co. from $75,000 to $95,000 in order to cover a one-year time extension resulting in additional costs. This agreement was originally dated January 19, 2012, and was subsequently amended on January 19, 2013, extending the term of the agreement to January 18, 2014. This Board item amends the term of the agreement to January 17, 2015 and augments the current contract from $95,000 to $113,000 as a result of this one-year extension and additional work assigned.  This extended time related to the developer selection process including seeking/obtaining of additional information from the RFP's, review/evaluation of such additional information, and corresponding coordination with District staff (and District legal counsel), which resulted in additional time and cost.
	 
The four primary reasons for the requested contract amendment are as follows:
Consultants attended and participated in a total number of meetings that substantially exceeded the number of meetings called for in the Scope of Work. The majority of these additional meetings related to the District’s process for review, evaluation and analysis of the proposals submitted to the District, including preparation of District staff recommendations for review/consideration by the Board Land Sub-committee. 
The Scope of Work (as amended on August 2, 2013) called for a total of nineteen (19) meetings for Tasks 1, 2 and 3. To date, A. Plescia & Co. and Gruen Gruen + Associates either individually or collectively have participated in twenty-seven (27) meetings and/or telephone conference calls related to the District’s review/evaluation of the proposals submitted in response to the Request for Proposals (RFP) issued on May 17, 2013.
Consultants prepared additional review, evaluation and analysis of supplemental information requested by District of certain respondents to the RFP. This will require certain revisions to the draft proposal evaluation report previously submitted to the District in September 2013 that presents the consulting team’s analysis of the subject proposals. 
Consultants participated in an additional Board of Trustee Land Sub-committee (December 3, 2013) that not only required the additional time for consultants to participate in the subject meeting, but also required consultants to expend additional time associated with preparation and submittal of written information (agendas, analysis, etc.), resulting in follow-up with the Board Land Sub-committee directions from their December 3, 2013 meeting over the next few weeks. 
Consultants will attend and participate in meetings with the Board of Trustees in February 2014 (and/or March 2014) regarding the Board’s review/consideration of District staff recommendations for selection of private sector developer(s) for disposition and development of the subject property (two meetings).
As shown above, the work completed to date as requested/authorized by the District has required an additional adjustment to the budget and time involved in the Scope of Work. The recommendation is that the Board of Trustees approves this contract amendment to extend the term of the agreement to January 17, 2015 and augment the contract by $18,000.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the contract amendment of $18,000 with A. Plescia & Co., an independent contractor providing services for the development of District owned land adjacent to Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. Board Policy 6100 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts and purchase orders exceeding the current bid limit of $84,100 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts that, although are not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.

items.item_details:
On May 14, 2013 the Board of Trustees approved the utilization of the Design-Build delivery method for the Joint-Use 21st Century Post-Secondary Education Center.  Prior to the commencement of the Design-Build phase the design requirements of the project will need to be established.
	 
The Design Professional (LPA, Inc.) has been tasked with establishing the building and site needs required to accommodate the program curriculum developed by both San Jose Evergreen Community College District and Milpitas Unified School District.  The resulting Design Program documents will form the âBasis of Designâ to be used by the Design Build entity in the design and construction of the project.  The Design Professional will help tailor the needs of the program to meet the current construction budget of approximately $6,000,000.  The Agreement includes allowances for the following optional additional services; assistance in the selection of the Design-Build entity, Design Phase Support and Construction Phase Support.  A separate agreement will be presented to the Board to complete the Design Build phase of the project after a Design Build entity has been selected.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve an Agreement with LPA, Inc. dated February 12, 2014 for Programming Services in the amount of $132,885 for the Joint-Use 21st Century Post-Secondary Education Center.
items.item_text: Measure G-2004 Bond: Agreement between SJECCD and LPA, Inc. for Programming Services of the Joint-Use 21st Century Post-Secondary Education Center.
items.item_text_raw: 2. Measure G-2004 Bond: Agreement between SJECCD and LPA, Inc. for Programming Services of the Joint-Use 21st Century Post-Secondary Education Center.

items.item_details:
At the Board meetings held March 13, 2012 and June 12, 2012, the Board was presented with information and details by the Program Management team and District legal counsel on the Lease/Leaseback project delivery method.  Subsequently, on July 9, 2013 the Board approved this method for the Physical Education Gymnasium project at San Jose City College.
	 
In keeping with that process, a Request for Qualifications (RFQ) for Lease/Leaseback Construction Services, including preconstruction services was issued on October 14, 2013.  Seven Statements of Qualifications (SOQ’s) were received on November 14, 2013.  A Selection Committee comprised of District staff and College staff and faculty scored the SOQ’s, short-listed and then interviewed three contractors.  These three contractors then submitted sealed proposals for lump sum preconstruction services fee and fee percentages for construction services.
	 
Based on the combination of points awarded and its fee proposal, Sundt Construction Inc. of San Jose, California was determined to be the successful firm by providing the “best value” to the District.  Their proposal includes a fixed fee for preconstruction services (including design support, subcontract bidding and Guaranteed Maximum Price development) of $87,000 and construction service fee percentages to be applied to the Guaranteed Maximum Price.  The Guaranteed Maximum Price will be brought to the Board for approval and execution of Site & Facilities Leases per conventional Lease/Leaseback contracting.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve an Agreement with Sundt Construction Inc. for preconstruction services in the amount of $87,000 and construction service fee percentages to be applied to the Guaranteed Maximum Price for the Physical Education Gymnasium project at San Jose City College.
items.item_text: Measure G-2004 Bond: Award of Lease-Leaseback Contract for Preconstruction Services – San Jose City College PE Gym
items.item_text_raw: 3. Measure G-2004 Bond: Award of Lease-Leaseback Contract for Preconstruction Services – San Jose City College PE Gym

items.item_details: On December 11, 2012, the Board approved the Design Services Agreement for the Photography Lab Relocation Project with Artik Art & Architecture.  Following completion of the design, the District invited bids from General Contractors for the Project.  On June 11, 2013, the Board approved the Construction Agreement for Premier Builders, Inc. to perform the work.  On June 14, 2013, construction operations began and on October 15, 2013 major construction operations were completed.  All construction work has been approved by the Architect of Record, all closeout documents have been received, change orders have been approved and all contracts have been closed.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Notice of Completion for the San José City College Photography Lab Relocation project.

items.item_details:
On July 9, 2013 the Board agreed to enter into a contract with JKL Construction Services, Inc. to provide construction services to upgrade and extend underground utilities including power, telecommunications, gas, heating and cooling water to buildings on campus.
	 
Construction contracts often times experience unforeseen conditions, coordination gaps and/or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  During excavation several unforeseen conditions and unmarked utilities were encountered which required revisions to the design drawings.  In addition, the contractor uncovered existing utilities that were leaking and required repair.  JKL Construction Services, Inc. has submitted change proposals, which were reviewed for accuracy and conformance with the Contract Documents.
	 
Original Contract Amount                 $2,880,567
Previous Approved Changes           $     40,695
Change Order No. 005                     $       7,852
	 
Total Contract and Changes            $2,929,114
	 
The net change to JKL Construction Services, Inc. contract as a result of all changes issued will be $48,547, which equates to 1.7% of the base contract.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 005 for JKL Construction Services, Inc. in the amount of $7,852 for the San Jose City College Utility Extension Project.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: San Jose City College - Utility Extension Project #G2010.0052, Project #31110 Change Order No. 005
items.item_text_raw: 5. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: San Jose City College - Utility Extension Project #G2010.0052, Project #31110 Change Order No. 005

items.item_details:
On April 10, 2012 the Board agreed to enter into a contract with Lionakis to design services for the Automotive Technology Project at Evergreen Valley College. 
	 
Design contracts often times experience unforeseen conditions and/or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract price and/or duration in the form of an amendment.  Project Assignment Amendment #002 includes preparation of a rough grading and excavation plan for coordination with another project to construct a new campus loop road adjacent to the Automotive Technology site.  Lionakis submitted written pricing proposals for changes detailed in the Agenda attachment that includes additional work.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
The previous PAA amendment increased the design contract value to be based on the final programmed project cost.  The item in this amendment results in an add to the contract of $1,650.
	 
Original Contract Amount                 $668,350
Previous Approved Changes            $320,815
Amendment #002                                 $1,650
Total Contract and Changes             $990,815
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Project Assignment Agreement #002 for Lionakis in the amount of $1,650 for the Automotive Technology Project at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: EVC - Automotive Technology – Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) #002
items.item_text_raw: 6. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: EVC - Automotive Technology – Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) #002

items.item_details:
On May 14, 2013 the Board agreed to enter into a contract with Swenson & Associates to provide construction services to renovate and upgrade the Central Plan and Police Station at Evergreen Valley College. 
	 
Construction contracts often times experience unforeseen conditions, coordination gaps and/or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order #006 includes modifications to underground abandoned utilities, modification to a water line tie-in location, excavation for a hydronic piping anchor and revision to the electronic security system.  Swenson & Associates submitted written pricing proposals for changes detailed in the Agenda attachment that include additional or deleted materials, equipment, labor, time extensions as applicable and the prescribed mark-ups.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
The four items in this change order result in an add to the contract of $34,852.
	 
Original Contract Amount                $9,965,000
Previous Approved Changes             $247,351
Change Order #006                              $34,852
Total Contract and Changes         $10,247,203
	 
The total net change to Swensonâs contract as a result of all Change Orders is $282,203, which equates to 2.83% of the base contract.
	 
Original Contract Completion Date                   June 27, 2014
Prior Approved Change to Completion date     July 14, 2014
Completion Date with this change                     July 14, 2014
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order #006 for Swenson & Associates in the amount of $34,852 for the Central Plant and Police Station Renovation Project at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: EVC - Central Plant and Police Station Renovation - Change Order #006
items.item_text_raw: 7. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: EVC - Central Plant and Police Station Renovation - Change Order #006

items.item_details:
SJECC is refreshing their hardware and software infrastructure to achieve improved efficiency,
effectiveness, and business continuity preparedness. The overall effort includes new hardware and software. A major portion of the effort is the migration of the Ellucian Colleague application suite from the existing hardware and database (Oracle) to new hardware and the Microsoft SQL server database, with attendant business process review (to identify opportunities for improvement) and improved data manipulation and reporting.  The project duration is 33 months.
	 
A public bidding process was conducted December, 2013 through January, 2014. A Request for Qualifications/Request for Proposal was issued, seeking technical consultant firms qualified to provide the District with technical expertise, project management leadership, and organizational change skills to lead the conversion of the ERP software platform and the implementation of business analytic reporting.  
	 
The RFQ/RFP was prepared and the bidding process conducted by a committee which included the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services, representatives of the District Purchasing Department and the District ITSS staff, and an outside technical consultant (Mick Holsclaw).  To avoid conflict of interest in responding to the RFQ/RFP, representatives of CampusWorks were not involved in the process.
	 
The RFQ/RFP was posted on the Districtâs Purchasing website and advertised in the local newspaper of record on December 20, 2013, December 27, 2013, and January 3, 2014.  Invitations to Bid were emailed to eight firms identified as potential bidders.  CampusWorks was the only respondent to the Request for Qualifications.  The committee considers CampusWorks to be a qualified respondent.  The RFP process was completed on a revised schedule (eliminating the competitive decision steps of the original timeline).  On January 29 the committee interviewed CampusWorks and confirmed them as the selected vendor for this bid.
	 
In negotiations it was identified that the District could achieve a savings by contracting separately with CampusWorks and ASR Analytics, resulting in a contract to CampusWorks for $2,678,562.50 and a time and expenses contract to ASR Analytics not to exceed $277,440.00 for a project total amount of $2,956,003.00.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees award contracts for Bid Proposal G2010.0069 Ellucian Colleague Conversion to MS SQL & Related Upgrades Project to the CampusWorks team (a contract to CampusWorks for $2,678,562.50 and a contract to ASR Analytics not to exceed $277,440.00) in the total amount of $2,956,003.00.
items.item_text: Award of Contracts for Bid Proposal G2010.0069 Ellucian Colleague Conversion to MS SQL & Related Upgrades Project
items.item_text_raw: 8. Award of Contracts for Bid Proposal G2010.0069 Ellucian Colleague Conversion to MS SQL & Related Upgrades Project

items.item_details:
The HVAC and Plumbing Upgrades Project provides the following scope of work for various buildings at the San Jose City College Campus:
	 
Business Building
The Work of this project consists of, but is not limited to:
	 
Replace the built up air handler located in the mechanical room with an indoor packaged air handler with external mounted VFD for the supply fan.
Reconnect to existing supply ductwork and outside air louvers.
Demolish the abandoned equipment located in the courtyard by the mechanical room.  
Replace the return grilles in the classrooms with the filtered return grilles.  
Remove the existing filters and filter supports from the existing fan coils and replace with a flexible duct connector.
	 
Cosmetology/Reprographics Building
The Work of this project consists of, but is not limited to:
	 
Conduct site utility survey to locate existing utilities that may be affected by the installation of new underground sanitary sewer piping.
Install approximately 30’ of new 4” sanitary sewer line and 10’ of 6” sanitary sewer line.
Cap and abandon the existing sanitary sewer line that has been bypassed.
Provide cleanouts at each new point of connection.
	 
Student Services Center
The Work consists of, but is not limited to:
	 
Install new domestic water heater and tempering station in second floor mechanical room.
District shall provide water heater for contractor to install.
On all 1st and 2nd floor men’s and women’s student/public restroom sinks install new thermostatic mixing valves.
Total of sixteen (16) bathroom sinks shall be retrofitted with new mixing valves, coordinate with district for any additional staff restroom sink locations.
	 
Applied Science Building
The Work consists of, but is not limited to:
	 
Two (2) Sullair air compressor (1100 EL Series) located in the mechanical room shall be re-piped per manufacturer’s instructions.  Refer to detail 7 on sheet M-5.2 for manufacturer piping installation diagram.
Contractor shall verify which (if any) components need to be replaced and coordinate with District prior to repiping.
	 
On January 28, 2014 construction bids were received for construction.  The project was posted on the District’s purchasing website, advertised in local papers on January 7th and January 14th.  In addition the advertisement was published at local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms.
	 
Environmental Systems, Inc.                                       $ 276,000
American Air Conditioning Plumbing & Heating          $ 387,783
S&H Construction                                                        $ 790,000  
	 
Environmental Systems, Inc. from Santa Clara, CA was determined the lowest bidder in the amount of $276,000.  It should be noted that Bid Alternate# 1 is included in the bid price of $276,000, although the form for this alternate was not completed by Environmental Systems, Inc.  Written acknowledgement of this matter has been received and accepted from Environmental Systems, Inc. on January 31, 2014.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve issuance of a construction contract to Environmental Systems, Inc. in the amount of $276,000 for the HVAC and Plumbing Upgrades Project at San Jose City College.

items.item_details:
The California Community College Trustees (CCCT) board serves a major role within the Community College League of California. Meeting five times a year, the twenty-one member board provides leadership and direction to ensure a strong voice for locally elected governing board members.
		 
From January 1 through February 15, nominations for membership on the CCCT board will be accepted in the League office. Nominations are to be made by member district board of trustees, and each district may nominate only members of its board. Each nominee must be a local community college district trustee, other than the student trustee, and must have consented to be nominated. Only one trustee per district may serve on the board.
		 
This information was made available to SJECCD Trustees on January 14, 2014, and Board President Lease informed the Board of Trustees of his interest. It is recommended, therefore, that the Board of Trustees nominate Trustee Jeffrey Lease to serve as a member of the CCCT board.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees nominate Trustee Jeffrey Lease to serve on the California Community College Trustees (CCCT) Board.

items.item_details:
The previous Measure G 2004 Bond List Revision was approved by the Board of Trustees on November 12, 2013. Revisions are presented to the Board on a quarterly basis and as needed. 
                                                                                                                                                                               
This proposed Bond List Revision reflects the efforts to plan and prioritize Measure G-2004 Bond projects at Evergreen Valley College and San Jose City College.  The changes included in this Bond List Revision align project scope and budget with planned implementation efforts to gain efficiency and economy of scale. There are no revisions to District projects in this request.  
	 
The Measure G-2004 Bond List Revision dated February 11, 2014 includes the following actions:
	 
Project 122: Physical Education Gymnasium
San Jose City Collegeâs portion of allocated interest earnings through the period June 30, 2013 in the amount of $964,360 is being transferred from Project 399- Program Contingency to Project 122-Physical Education Gymnasium to accommodate scope.
	 
Project 399: Program Contingency
San Jose City Collegeâs portion of allocated interest earnings through the period June 30, 2013 in the amount of $964,360 is being transferred from Project 399- Program Contingency to Project 122- Physical Education Gymnasium to accommodate scope.
Record Fiscal Year 2013-14 Quarter 1 interest earnings in the amount of $10,963.28.
	 
	 
These Bond List Revisions have been approved by the Evergreen Valley College and San Jose City College Vice Presidents of Administrative Services and the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees review and approve the revisions to the Measure G - 2004 bond list, as presented.

items.item_details:
The Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee, appointed by the Board of Trustees, has a responsibility under the provisions of Proposition 39 to inform the public, review expenditures and present an annual report to the Board of Trustees.
	 
The web-based Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee’s 2012-2013 Annual Report is presented to the Board of Trustee’s for acceptance by the 2012-2013 Committee Chair, Mr. Joseph Becker.
	 
This report is available for review using the following web link: http://cboc.sjebond.com/AR1213/
A printable version of this web-based report is also attached.

items.item_details:
As part of the accountability measures for the Measure G-2010 Bond Program, the management team for the program has put into place a formal process for managing, tracking and presenting to the Board of Trustees all revisions to the Measure G-2010 individual project names, scopes and budgets.  This process adheres to the accountability standards outlined by Proposition 39 and provides transparency in the evolution of the project list.
	 
These revisions are the result of careful coordination and realignment with the current Facilities Master Plans and the planned implementation of the projects at each campus.
	 
Measure G-2010 Bond List Revision #7 includes the following actions:
	 
Project 32110: Demolition – Roble/Acacia
Project savings in the amount of $1,260.84 is being transferred from completed Project 32310 – Energy Efficiency- Photovoltaic to Project 32110 – Demolition- Roble/Acacia. 
	 
Project 32310: Energy Efficiency- Photovoltaics
Project savings in the amount of $1,260.84 is being transferred from completed Project 32310 – Energy Efficiency- Photovoltaic to Project 32110 – Demolition- Roble/Acacia. 
	 
Project 32313: Parking Lot and Street Maintenance
Revise scope to "New, and repairs to existing, vehicle/pedestrian pathways, surfaces and related features (e.g. roadways, walkways, curbs/gutters, lighting, signage and graphics, painting, landscaping, utilities)" to better describe the project scope.
	 
Project 39699: Program Contingency
Record Fiscal Year 2013-14, Quarter 1 bond interest earnings in the amount of $37,042.86.
	 
These Bond List Revisions have been approved by the Evergreen Valley College and San Jose City College Vice Presidents of Administrative Services and the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees review and approve the revisions to the Measure G - 2010 bond list, as presented.

items.item_details: On January 31, 2014, President Obama issued a Presidential Proclamation proclaiming February 2014 as National African American History Month. In support of this proclamation and in celebration of the achievements of African American faculty, administrators, staff and students, Evergreen Valley College and San Jose City College organized many events in which African American culture was celebrated. It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution No. 021114-2 in support of February 2014 as Black/African American History Month.

items.item_details:
The Districtâs bond underwriters, RBC Capital Markets and Piper Jaffray, will be presenting information on the issuance of Measure G-2004: Series C, Measure G-2010: Series C, and the refunding of General Obligation Bonds.
	 
The last issuance of Measure G-2004, Series C, will be approximately $31 million dollars.  The third issuance of Measure G-2010, Series C, is expected to be approximately $120 million.  The refunding of outstanding Prior Bonds in an aggregate principal amount is expected not-to-exceed $140 million.  All benefits from the refunding will be delivered to the property owners in the District.  These three financial activities have been scheduled to coincide for cost effectiveness. 
	 
Draft Resolutions and each accompanying draft agenda item for the Resolutions, Preliminary Official Statement, Escrow Agreements (refunding documents), and Contracts of Purchase for these transactions have been included for Board review.  The final resolutions and associated documents will be brought to the Board of Trustees for approval on March 11, 2014.
	 
The next steps toward issuance of Measure G-2004 Series C, Measure G-2010 Series C and the refunding of Prior Bonds are as follows:
	 
March 4, 2014: Presentations to bond credit rating agencies.
	 
March 11, 2014: Board of Trustees meeting to approve resolutions for bond financing activities.
	 
April 1 through April 15, 2014: Pre-sale and Sale Activities
	 
Mid-April: Closing of bond financings/bond proceeds received by the District.

items.item_details:
Over the years various manufactured materials and products have been incorporated into the District’s facilities.  Cost savings and efficiencies are realized by minimizing the quantity of parts inventoried by the District Maintenance Department and contracts with service companies, as well as training or tools needed to maintain multiple brands of products.  The California Public Contract Code acknowledges these savings and efficiencies in Section 3400 (c), by allowing the designation of materials, products, things or services by specific brand or trade name in Invitations for Bids or Requests for Proposals for certain purposes.  These include the desire or need to match other products in use on a completed campus facility or on a facility being completed. (PCC Section 3400 (c) 2)
	 
The Public Contract Code Section 3400 (c) 1 also allows for the specific brand or trade name be used if executing a field test or experiment in order to determine a product’s suitability for future use.  Recently the Evergreen Valley College Facilities and Safety Committee selected a specific brand of LED exterior light fixtures (listed in the second table below) to be installed and tested at the South Campus Development and New Automotive Technology Building projects in order to establish a campus-wide standard for safe, energy efficient and attractive fixtures that presents a cohesive and complementary appearance with other architectural elements on campus.  If these light fixtures are deemed acceptable by the Committee, a Board finding would allow subsequent Invitations for Bids or Requests for Proposals to designate these fixtures by specific brand name per Public Contract Code Section 3400 (c) 1.   San Jose City College is expected to be selecting exterior lighting in the near future that your Board will be asked to make a similar finding and add to the table of products listed below.
	 
At a subsequent meeting it will be recommended that the materials and products listed in the tables below be allowed to be designated by specific brand or trade name, with substituted products not allowed, in Invitations for Bids or Requests for Proposals involving District facilities.  The current development of the District Design Standards may result in future recommendations to the Board to add materials, products, things or services that meet the criteria established in Public Contract Code Section 3400 to these lists.
	 
	 
Material, Product, Thing or Service (per PCC Section 3400 (c) 2)
Specific Brand or Trade Name
Door Lock Hardware
Schlage
Door Closers
LCN
Door panic bars/exit devices/keyed removable mullions
Von Duprin
Powered Control Locks & Automatic Operators
Schlage
Building Energy Management System/HVAC Controls 
Johnson Controls (JCI) -– Metasys System Controllers, Lonmark listed or BacNet JCI
Actuators – for HVAC dampers & control valves
Bellimo
Lighting Controls
Wattstopper
Fire Alarm System
Simplex 
Irrigation Controller & Cable
Rainmaster
Irrigation Controller Inspection and  Certification.
John Deere/United Green Tech
Quick Coupling Valve
Rainbird 
Remote Control Valve
Griswold
	 
	 
	 
Material, Product, Thing or Service (per PCC Section 3400 (c) 1)
Specific Brand or Trade Name
Exterior Lighting – EVC only
Bega

items.item_details:
All new bills for the 2014 California Legislative Session are required to be submitted by the February 21, 2014 deadline.  After an analysis of bills with relevance to SJECCD is conducted, the Board will receive a summary of each bill with action recommendations.
	 
In the interim, a report will be provided to the Board that describes recent SJECCD legislative activity and updated information on two legislative initiatives that have already been introduced and for which we believe will be of interest to SJECCD.  Namely:  
SCA-5 (Senator Ed Hernandez) which proposes a constitutional amendment to be placed before the voters to, in essence, reverse Prop 209 with respect to public education.   And SB 850 (Senator Block) which would set the stage for a baccalaureate degree pilot program.
items.item_text: Legislative Report
items.item_text_raw: 5. Legislative Report

items.item_details:
At the January 28, 2014, Governing Board Meeting, the Board of Trustees reviewed a draft document of governance policies. which were developed over the course of three board meetings in December 2013. The Board provided edits at the meeting. One key issue determined by the Board was that some of the language in the draft governance policies were already contained in Board Policies Chapter Two. President Lease stated that as a next step, the Board would provide a side-by-side comparison of these two sets of policies. The Board also requested a legal review of some of the policies, including some of the wording utilized in the policies; and this review will take place at a future meeting with legal counsel present. 
	 
It was also determined at the January 28 meeting that the Board needed to review the current Board committees. President Lease reviewed four criteria for board committees as outlined in the governance policy on committees. He requested that Board Committee Chairs review their committees in view of these criteria and be prepared to discuss with all board members at a future board meeting.
	 
Since legal counsel has not had ample opportunity to do a review of the draft governance policies, it was decided that at the February 11 board meeting, the board would work on a comparison of the language contained in draft governance policies document and BP Chapter Two and also hold a discussion on board committees. The draft documents are attached to this agenda item.
